name: Emperor Haile Selassie I
title: Emperor of Ethiopia (1930-1974)
biography: Born Tafari Makonnen, Haile Selassie was Ethiopia's regent from 1916 to 1930 and emperor from 1930 to 1974. He is a defining figure in modern Ethiopian history, who led the country through Italian occupation, modernization efforts, and onto the world stage.
achievements: Secured Ethiopia's membership in the League of Nations (1923)
Led resistance against Italian occupation
Established the Organization of African Unity (OAU) in 1963
Modernized Ethiopia's education system

name: Emperor Menelik II
title: Emperor of Ethiopia (1889-1913)
biography: Menelik II was Emperor of Ethiopia from 1889 to 1913. He expanded Ethiopia to its modern territorial boundaries and successfully resisted European colonization by defeating Italy at the Battle of Adwa in 1896.
achievements: Victory at the Battle of Adwa (1896)
Expanded and unified modern Ethiopia
Established Addis Ababa as the capital city
Introduced modern infrastructure including railways and telegraph

name: Empress Taytu Betul
title: Empress of Ethiopia (1889-1913)
biography: Taytu Betul was the wife of Emperor Menelik II and a powerful empress in her own right. She was a key military strategist during the First Italo-Ethiopian War and played a significant role in founding Addis Ababa.
achievements: Co-founded Addis Ababa
Led her own battalion in the Battle of Adwa
Established the first modern hotel in Ethiopia
Resisted Italian diplomatic pressure before the war

name: Emperor Tewodros II
title: Emperor of Ethiopia (1855-1868)
biography: Born Kassa Hailu, Tewodros II was Emperor of Ethiopia from 1855 to 1868. He is known for his attempts to unify and modernize Ethiopia after the Zemene Mesafint (Era of the Princes).
achievements: Began the unification of Ethiopia
Created the first professional standing army
Attempted to modernize Ethiopia's military and administration
Challenged the political power of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church

name: Abebe Bikila
title: Olympic Marathon Champion
biography: Abebe Bikila was an Ethiopian marathon runner who won Ethiopia's first Olympic gold medal at the 1960 Rome Olympics, running the marathon barefoot. He successfully defended his title at the 1964 Tokyo Olympics.
achievements: First African to win an Olympic gold medal (Rome, 1960)
Won two consecutive Olympic marathon gold medals
Set world record times in both Olympic victories
National hero who inspired generations of Ethiopian runners

name: Afewerk Tekle
title: Artist
biography: Afewerk Tekle (1932-2012) was Ethiopia's most celebrated artist. His most famous work, 'African Heritage,' is a stained glass panel at the Africa Hall in Addis Ababa.
achievements: Created the stained glass windows for St. George's Cathedral in Addis Ababa
Designed the massive 'Total Liberation of Africa' stained glass in Africa Hall
Received numerous international awards and honors
Appointed as Ethiopia's Honorary Cultural Ambassador

name: Zera Yacob
title: Philosopher
biography: Zera Yacob (1599-1692) was an Ethiopian philosopher whose work 'Hatata' (Inquiry) developed a rational philosophy centered on the idea that human reason should be the ultimate judge of religious truth.
achievements: Developed rational philosophical arguments in the 17th century
Advocated for religious tolerance and rational inquiry
Created one of Africa's most important philosophical texts
Challenged religious dogmatism through logical reasoning

name: Empress Zewditu
title: Empress of Ethiopia (1916-1930)
biography: Zewditu was Empress of Ethiopia from 1916 to 1930, the first female head of an internationally recognized state in Africa in the 19th and 20th centuries. She was the daughter of Emperor Menelik II.
achievements: First female monarch of a recognized modern African state
Maintained Ethiopian independence during a turbulent period
Preserved Ethiopian Orthodox traditions
Navigated complex political relationships with European powers
